instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Kernel Panicking Once or Twice A Week
threads.message:
Hello,

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook that is kernel panic'ing. We did an SSD replacement because there were definitely some faults on it however the kernel panicking is still happening. I redid the solder on <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> (ISL628) and even changed it, I also changed the SSD a second time, however the kernel panicking is still being reported by the customer. The panic report shows that it is not isolated to just one CPU core. It can happen on any. How should I go about troubleshooting this?

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Kernel Panicking Once or Twice A Week
